trans-unit.source: Provision and deploy microservices predictably in Azure
trans-unit.target: Provision and deploy microservices predictably in Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to deploy an application composed of microservices in Azure App Service as a single unit and in a predictable manner using JSON resource group templates and PowerShell scripting.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to deploy an application composed of microservices in Azure App Service as a single unit and in a predictable manner using JSON resource group templates and PowerShell scripting.

trans-unit.source: Provision and deploy microservices predictably in Azure
trans-unit.target: Provision and deploy microservices predictably in Azure

trans-unit.source: This tutorial shows how to provision and deploy an application composed of [microservices](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microservices) in [Azure App Service](/services/app-service/) as a single unit and in a predictable manner using JSON resource group templates and PowerShell scripting.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial shows how to provision and deploy an application composed of [microservices](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microservices) in [Azure App Service](/services/app-service/) as a single unit and in a predictable manner using JSON resource group templates and PowerShell scripting.

trans-unit.source: When provisioning and deploying high-scale applications that are composed of highly decoupled microservices, repeatability and predictability are crucial to success.
trans-unit.target: When provisioning and deploying high-scale applications that are composed of highly decoupled microservices, repeatability and predictability are crucial to success.

trans-unit.source: [Azure App Service](/services/app-service/) enables you to create microservices that include web apps, mobile apps, API apps, and logic apps.
trans-unit.target: [Azure App Service](/services/app-service/) enables you to create microservices that include web apps, mobile apps, API apps, and logic apps.

trans-unit.source: [Azure Resource Manager](../resource-group-overview.md) enables you to manage all the microservices as a unit, together with resource dependencies such as database and source control settings.
trans-unit.target: [Azure Resource Manager](../resource-group-overview.md) enables you to manage all the microservices as a unit, together with resource dependencies such as database and source control settings.

trans-unit.source: Now, you can also deploy such an application using JSON templates and simple PowerShell scripting.
trans-unit.target: Now, you can also deploy such an application using JSON templates and simple PowerShell scripting.

trans-unit.source: What you will do
trans-unit.target: What you will do

trans-unit.source: In the tutorial, you will deploy an application that includes:
trans-unit.target: In the tutorial, you will deploy an application that includes:

trans-unit.source: Two web apps (i.e. two microservices)
trans-unit.target: Two web apps (i.e. two microservices)

trans-unit.source: A backend SQL Database
trans-unit.target: A backend SQL Database

trans-unit.source: App settings, connection strings, and source control
trans-unit.target: App settings, connection strings, and source control

trans-unit.source: Application insights, alerts, autoscaling settings
trans-unit.target: Application insights, alerts, autoscaling settings

trans-unit.source: Tools you will use
trans-unit.target: Tools you will use

trans-unit.source: In this tutorial, you will use the following tools.
trans-unit.target: In this tutorial, you will use the following tools.

trans-unit.source: Since it’s not comprehensive discussion on tools, I’m going to stick to the end-to-end scenario and just give you a brief intro to each, and where you can find more information on it.
trans-unit.target: Since it’s not comprehensive discussion on tools, I’m going to stick to the end-to-end scenario and just give you a brief intro to each, and where you can find more information on it.

trans-unit.source: Azure Resource Manager templates (JSON)
trans-unit.target: Azure Resource Manager templates (JSON)

trans-unit.source: Every time you create a web app in Azure App Service, for example, Azure Resource Manager uses a JSON template to create the entire resource group with the component resources.
trans-unit.target: Every time you create a web app in Azure App Service, for example, Azure Resource Manager uses a JSON template to create the entire resource group with the component resources.

trans-unit.source: A complex template from the [Azure Marketplace](/marketplace) like the [Scalable WordPress](/marketplace/partners/wordpress/scalablewordpress/) app can include the MySQL database, storage accounts, the App Service plan, the web app itself, alert rules, app settings, autoscale settings, and more, and all these templates are available to you through PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: A complex template from the [Azure Marketplace](/marketplace) like the [Scalable WordPress](/marketplace/partners/wordpress/scalablewordpress/) app can include the MySQL database, storage accounts, the App Service plan, the web app itself, alert rules, app settings, autoscale settings, and more, and all these templates are available to you through PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: For information on how to download and use these templates, see [Using Azure PowerShell with Azure Resource Manager](../powershell-azure-resource-manager.md).
trans-unit.target: For information on how to download and use these templates, see [Using Azure PowerShell with Azure Resource Manager](../powershell-azure-resource-manager.md).

trans-unit.source: For more information on the Azure Resource Manager templates, see [Authoring Azure Resource Manager Templates](../resource-group-authoring-templates.md)
trans-unit.target: For more information on the Azure Resource Manager templates, see [Authoring Azure Resource Manager Templates](../resource-group-authoring-templates.md)

trans-unit.source: Azure SDK 2.6 for Visual Studio
trans-unit.target: Azure SDK 2.6 for Visual Studio

trans-unit.source: The newest SDK contains improvements to the Resource Manager template support in the JSON editor.
trans-unit.target: The newest SDK contains improvements to the Resource Manager template support in the JSON editor.

trans-unit.source: You can use this to quickly create a resource group template from scratch or open an existing JSON template (such as a downloaded gallery template) for modification, populate the parameters file, and even deploy the resource group directly from an Azure Resource Group solution.
trans-unit.target: You can use this to quickly create a resource group template from scratch or open an existing JSON template (such as a downloaded gallery template) for modification, populate the parameters file, and even deploy the resource group directly from an Azure Resource Group solution.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Azure SDK 2.6 for Visual Studio](/blog/2015/04/29/announcing-the-azure-sdk-2-6-for-net/).
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Azure SDK 2.6 for Visual Studio](/blog/2015/04/29/announcing-the-azure-sdk-2-6-for-net/).

trans-unit.source: Azure PowerShell 0.8.0 or later
trans-unit.target: Azure PowerShell 0.8.0 or later

trans-unit.source: Beginning in version 0.8.0, the Azure PowerShell installation includes the Azure Resource Manager module in addition to the Azure module.
trans-unit.target: Beginning in version 0.8.0, the Azure PowerShell installation includes the Azure Resource Manager module in addition to the Azure module.

trans-unit.source: This new module enables you to script the deployment of resource groups.
trans-unit.target: This new module enables you to script the deployment of resource groups.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Using Azure PowerShell with Azure Resource Manager](../powershell-azure-resource-manager.md)
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Using Azure PowerShell with Azure Resource Manager](../powershell-azure-resource-manager.md)

trans-unit.source: Azure Resource Explorer
trans-unit.target: Azure Resource Explorer

trans-unit.source: This [preview tool](https://resources.azure.com) enables you to explore the JSON definitions of all the resource groups in your subscription and the individual resources.
trans-unit.target: This [preview tool](https://resources.azure.com) enables you to explore the JSON definitions of all the resource groups in your subscription and the individual resources.

trans-unit.source: In the tool, you can edit the JSON definitions of a resource, delete an entire hierarchy of resources, and create new resources.
trans-unit.target: In the tool, you can edit the JSON definitions of a resource, delete an entire hierarchy of resources, and create new resources.

trans-unit.source: The information readily available in this tool is very helpful for template authoring because it shows you what properties you need to set for a particular type of resource, the correct values, etc. You can even create your resource group in the [Azure preview portal](https://portal.azure.com), then inspect its JSON definitions in the explorer tool to help you templatize the resource group.
trans-unit.target: The information readily available in this tool is very helpful for template authoring because it shows you what properties you need to set for a particular type of resource, the correct values, etc. You can even create your resource group in the [Azure preview portal](https://portal.azure.com), then inspect its JSON definitions in the explorer tool to help you templatize the resource group.

trans-unit.source: Deploy to Azure button
trans-unit.target: Deploy to Azure button

trans-unit.source: If you use GitHub for source control, you can put a [Deploy to Azure button](/blog/2014/11/13/deploy-to-azure-button-for-azure-websites-2/) into your README.MD, which enables a turn-key deployment UI to Azure.
trans-unit.target: If you use GitHub for source control, you can put a [Deploy to Azure button](/blog/2014/11/13/deploy-to-azure-button-for-azure-websites-2/) into your README.MD, which enables a turn-key deployment UI to Azure.

trans-unit.source: While you can do this for any simple web app, you can extend this to enable deploying an entire resource group by putting an azuredeploy.json file in the repository root.
trans-unit.target: While you can do this for any simple web app, you can extend this to enable deploying an entire resource group by putting an azuredeploy.json file in the repository root.

trans-unit.source: This JSON file, which contains the resource group template, will be used by the Deploy to Azure button to create the resource group.
trans-unit.target: This JSON file, which contains the resource group template, will be used by the Deploy to Azure button to create the resource group.

trans-unit.source: For an example, see the [ToDoApp](https://github.com/azure-appservice-samples/ToDoApp) sample, which you will use in this tutorial.
trans-unit.target: For an example, see the [ToDoApp](https://github.com/azure-appservice-samples/ToDoApp) sample, which you will use in this tutorial.

trans-unit.source: Get the sample resource group template
trans-unit.target: Get the sample resource group template

trans-unit.source: So now let’s get right to it.
trans-unit.target: So now let’s get right to it.

trans-unit.source: Navigate to the [ToDoApp](https://github.com/azure-appservice-samples/ToDoApp) App Service sample.
trans-unit.target: Navigate to the [ToDoApp](https://github.com/azure-appservice-samples/ToDoApp) App Service sample.

trans-unit.source: In readme.md, click **Deploy to Azure**.
trans-unit.target: In readme.md, click **Deploy to Azure**.

trans-unit.source: You’re taken to the [deploy-to-azure](https://deploy.azure.com) site and asked to input deployment parameters.
trans-unit.target: You’re taken to the [deploy-to-azure](https://deploy.azure.com) site and asked to input deployment parameters.

trans-unit.source: Notice that most of the fields are populated with the repository name and some random strings for you.
trans-unit.target: Notice that most of the fields are populated with the repository name and some random strings for you.

trans-unit.source: You can change all the fields if you want, but the only things you have to enter are the SQL Server administrative login and the password, then click **Next**.
trans-unit.target: You can change all the fields if you want, but the only things you have to enter are the SQL Server administrative login and the password, then click **Next**.

trans-unit.source: Next, click **Deploy** to start the deployment process.
trans-unit.target: Next, click **Deploy** to start the deployment process.

trans-unit.source: Once the process runs to completion, click the http://todoapp*XXXX*.azure.websites.net link to browse the deployed application.
trans-unit.target: Once the process runs to completion, click the http://todoapp*XXXX*.azure.websites.net link to browse the deployed application.

trans-unit.source: The UI would be a little slow when you first browse to it because the apps are just starting up, but convince yourself that it’s a fully-functional application.
trans-unit.target: The UI would be a little slow when you first browse to it because the apps are just starting up, but convince yourself that it’s a fully-functional application.

trans-unit.source: Back in the Deploy page, click the **Manage** link to see the new application in the Azure preview portal.
trans-unit.target: Back in the Deploy page, click the **Manage** link to see the new application in the Azure preview portal.

trans-unit.source: In the **Essentials** dropdown, click the resource group link.
trans-unit.target: In the **Essentials** dropdown, click the resource group link.

trans-unit.source: Note also that the web app is already connected to the GitHub repository under **External Project**.
trans-unit.target: Note also that the web app is already connected to the GitHub repository under **External Project**.

trans-unit.source: In the resource group blade, note that there are already two web apps and one SQL Database in the resource group.
trans-unit.target: In the resource group blade, note that there are already two web apps and one SQL Database in the resource group.

trans-unit.source: Everything that you just saw in a few short minutes is a fully deployed two-microservice application, with all the components, dependencies, settings, database, and continuous publishing, set up by an automated orchestration in Azure Resource Manager.
trans-unit.target: Everything that you just saw in a few short minutes is a fully deployed two-microservice application, with all the components, dependencies, settings, database, and continuous publishing, set up by an automated orchestration in Azure Resource Manager.

trans-unit.source: All this was done by two things:
trans-unit.target: All this was done by two things:

trans-unit.source: The Deploy to Azure button
trans-unit.target: The Deploy to Azure button

trans-unit.source: azuredeploy.json in the repo root
trans-unit.target: azuredeploy.json in the repo root

trans-unit.source: You can deploy this same application tens, hundreds, or thousands of times and have the exact same configuration every time.
trans-unit.target: You can deploy this same application tens, hundreds, or thousands of times and have the exact same configuration every time.

trans-unit.source: The repeatability and the predictability of this approach enables you to deploy high-scale applications with ease and confidence.
trans-unit.target: The repeatability and the predictability of this approach enables you to deploy high-scale applications with ease and confidence.

trans-unit.source: Examine (or edit) AZUREDEPLOY.JSON
trans-unit.target: Examine (or edit) AZUREDEPLOY.JSON

trans-unit.source: Now let’s look at how the GitHub repository was set up.
trans-unit.target: Now let’s look at how the GitHub repository was set up.

trans-unit.source: You will be using the JSON editor in the Azure .NET SDK, so if you haven’t already installed [Azure .NET SDK 2.6](/downloads/), do it now.
trans-unit.target: You will be using the JSON editor in the Azure .NET SDK, so if you haven’t already installed [Azure .NET SDK 2.6](/downloads/), do it now.

trans-unit.source: Clone the [ToDoApp](https://github.com/azure-appservice-samples/ToDoApp) repository using your favorite git tool.
trans-unit.target: Clone the [ToDoApp](https://github.com/azure-appservice-samples/ToDoApp) repository using your favorite git tool.

trans-unit.source: In the screenshot below, I’m doing this in the Team Explorer in Visual Studio 2013.
trans-unit.target: In the screenshot below, I’m doing this in the Team Explorer in Visual Studio 2013.

trans-unit.source: From the repository root, open azuredeploy.json in Visual Studio.
trans-unit.target: From the repository root, open azuredeploy.json in Visual Studio.

trans-unit.source: If you don’t see the JSON Outline pane, you need to install Azure .NET SDK.
trans-unit.target: If you don’t see the JSON Outline pane, you need to install Azure .NET SDK.

trans-unit.source: I’m not going to describe every detail of the JSON format, but the [More Resources](#resources) section has links for learning the resource group template language.
trans-unit.target: I’m not going to describe every detail of the JSON format, but the [More Resources](#resources) section has links for learning the resource group template language.

trans-unit.source: Here, I’m just going to show you the interesting features that can help you get started in making your own custom template for app deployment.
trans-unit.target: Here, I’m just going to show you the interesting features that can help you get started in making your own custom template for app deployment.

trans-unit.source: Parameters
trans-unit.target: Parameters

trans-unit.source: Take a look at the parameters section to see that most of these parameters are what the **Deploy to Azure** button prompts you to input.
trans-unit.target: Take a look at the parameters section to see that most of these parameters are what the **Deploy to Azure** button prompts you to input.

trans-unit.source: The site behind the **Deploy to Azure** button populates the input UI using the parameters defined in azuredeploy.json.
trans-unit.target: The site behind the **Deploy to Azure** button populates the input UI using the parameters defined in azuredeploy.json.

trans-unit.source: These parameters are used throughout the resource definitions, such as resource names, property values, etc.
trans-unit.target: These parameters are used throughout the resource definitions, such as resource names, property values, etc.

trans-unit.source: Resources
trans-unit.target: Resources

trans-unit.source: In the resources node, you can see that 4 top-level resources are defined, including a SQL Server instance, an App Service plan, and two web apps.
trans-unit.target: In the resources node, you can see that 4 top-level resources are defined, including a SQL Server instance, an App Service plan, and two web apps.

trans-unit.source: App Service plan
trans-unit.target: App Service plan

trans-unit.source: Let’s start with a simple root-level resource in the JSON.
trans-unit.target: Let’s start with a simple root-level resource in the JSON.

trans-unit.source: In the JSON Outline, click the App Service plan named **[hostingPlanName]** to highlight the corresponding JSON code.
trans-unit.target: In the JSON Outline, click the App Service plan named **[hostingPlanName]** to highlight the corresponding JSON code.

trans-unit.source: Note that the `type` element specifies the string for an App Service plan (it was called a server farm a long, long time ago), and other elements and properties are filled in using the parameters defined in the JSON file, and this resource doesn’t have any nested resources.
trans-unit.target: Note that the `type` element specifies the string for an App Service plan (it was called a server farm a long, long time ago), and other elements and properties are filled in using the parameters defined in the JSON file, and this resource doesn’t have any nested resources.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] Note also that the value of `apiVersion` tells Azure which version of the REST API to use the JSON resource definition with, and it can affect how the resource should be formatted inside the `{}`.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] Note also that the value of `apiVersion` tells Azure which version of the REST API to use the JSON resource definition with, and it can affect how the resource should be formatted inside the `{}`.

trans-unit.source: SQL Server
trans-unit.target: SQL Server

trans-unit.source: Next, click on the SQL Server resource named **SQLServer** in the JSON Outline.
trans-unit.target: Next, click on the SQL Server resource named **SQLServer** in the JSON Outline.

trans-unit.source: Note the following about the highlighted JSON code:
trans-unit.target: Note the following about the highlighted JSON code:

trans-unit.source: The use of parameters ensures that the created resources are named and configured in a way that makes them consistent with one another.
trans-unit.target: The use of parameters ensures that the created resources are named and configured in a way that makes them consistent with one another.

trans-unit.source: The SQLServer resource has two nested resources, each has a different value for `type`.
trans-unit.target: The SQLServer resource has two nested resources, each has a different value for `type`.

trans-unit.source: The nested resources inside `“resources”: […]`, where the database and the firewall rules are defined, have a `dependsOn` element that specifies the resource ID of the root-level SQLServer resource.
trans-unit.target: The nested resources inside `“resources”: […]`, where the database and the firewall rules are defined, have a `dependsOn` element that specifies the resource ID of the root-level SQLServer resource.

trans-unit.source: This tells Azure Resource Manager, “before you create this resource, that other resource must already exist; and if that other resource is defined in the template, then create that one first”.
trans-unit.target: This tells Azure Resource Manager, “before you create this resource, that other resource must already exist; and if that other resource is defined in the template, then create that one first”.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] For detailed information on how to use the `resourceId()` function, see [Azure Resource Manager Template Functions](../resource-group-template-functions.md).
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] For detailed information on how to use the `resourceId()` function, see [Azure Resource Manager Template Functions](../resource-group-template-functions.md).

trans-unit.source: The effect of the `dependsOn` element is that Azure Resource Manager can know which resources can be created in parallel and which resources must be created sequentially.
trans-unit.target: The effect of the `dependsOn` element is that Azure Resource Manager can know which resources can be created in parallel and which resources must be created sequentially.

trans-unit.source: Web app
trans-unit.target: Web app

trans-unit.source: Now, let’s move on to the actual web apps themselves, which are more complicated.
trans-unit.target: Now, let’s move on to the actual web apps themselves, which are more complicated.

trans-unit.source: Click the [variables(‘apiSiteName’)] web app in the JSON Outline to highlight its JSON code.
trans-unit.target: Click the [variables(‘apiSiteName’)] web app in the JSON Outline to highlight its JSON code.

trans-unit.source: You’ll notice that things are getting much more interesting.
trans-unit.target: You’ll notice that things are getting much more interesting.

trans-unit.source: For this purpose, I’ll talk about the features one by one:
trans-unit.target: For this purpose, I’ll talk about the features one by one:

trans-unit.source: Root resource
trans-unit.target: Root resource

trans-unit.source: The web app depends on two different resources.
trans-unit.target: The web app depends on two different resources.

trans-unit.source: This means that Azure Resource Manager will create the web app only after both the App Service plan and the SQL Server instance are created.
trans-unit.target: This means that Azure Resource Manager will create the web app only after both the App Service plan and the SQL Server instance are created.

trans-unit.source: App settings
trans-unit.target: App settings

trans-unit.source: The app settings are also defined as a nested resource.
trans-unit.target: The app settings are also defined as a nested resource.

trans-unit.source: In the `properties` element for `config/appsettings`, you have two app settings in the format `“<name>” : “<value>”`.
trans-unit.target: In the `properties` element for `config/appsettings`, you have two app settings in the format `“<name>” : “<value>”`.

trans-unit.source: `PROJECT` is a [KUDU setting](https://github.com/projectkudu/kudu/wiki/Customizing-deployments) that tells Azure deployment which project to use in a multi-project Visual Studio solution.
trans-unit.target: `PROJECT` is a [KUDU setting](https://github.com/projectkudu/kudu/wiki/Customizing-deployments) that tells Azure deployment which project to use in a multi-project Visual Studio solution.

trans-unit.source: I will show you later how source control is configured, but since the ToDoApp code is in a multi-project Visual Studio solution, we need this setting.
trans-unit.target: I will show you later how source control is configured, but since the ToDoApp code is in a multi-project Visual Studio solution, we need this setting.

trans-unit.source: `clientUrl` is simply an app setting that the application code uses.
trans-unit.target: `clientUrl` is simply an app setting that the application code uses.

trans-unit.source: Connection strings
trans-unit.target: Connection strings

trans-unit.source: The connection strings are also defined as a nested resource.
trans-unit.target: The connection strings are also defined as a nested resource.

trans-unit.source: In the `properties` element for `config/connectionstrings`, each connection string is also defined as a name:value pair, with the specific format of `“<name>” : {“value”: “…”, “type”: “…”}`.
trans-unit.target: In the `properties` element for `config/connectionstrings`, each connection string is also defined as a name:value pair, with the specific format of `“<name>” : {“value”: “…”, “type”: “…”}`.

trans-unit.source: For the `type` element, possible values are `MySql`, `SQLServer`, `SQLAzure`, and `Custom`.
trans-unit.target: For the `type` element, possible values are `MySql`, `SQLServer`, `SQLAzure`, and `Custom`.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.TIP] For a definitive list of the connection string types, run the following command in Azure PowerShell:
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.TIP] For a definitive list of the connection string types, run the following command in Azure PowerShell:

trans-unit.source: \[Enum]::GetNames("Microsoft.WindowsAzure.Commands.Utilities.Websites.Services.WebEntities.DatabaseType")
trans-unit.target: \[Enum]::GetNames("Microsoft.WindowsAzure.Commands.Utilities.Websites.Services.WebEntities.DatabaseType")

trans-unit.source: Source control
trans-unit.target: Source control

trans-unit.source: The source control settings are also defined as a nested resource.
trans-unit.target: The source control settings are also defined as a nested resource.

trans-unit.source: Azure Resource Manager uses this resource to configure continuous publishing (see caveat on `IsManualIntegration` later) and also to kick off the deployment of application code automatically during the processing of the JSON file.
trans-unit.target: Azure Resource Manager uses this resource to configure continuous publishing (see caveat on `IsManualIntegration` later) and also to kick off the deployment of application code automatically during the processing of the JSON file.

trans-unit.source: `RepoUrl` and `branch` should be pretty intuitive and should point to the Git repository and the name of the branch to publish from.
trans-unit.target: `RepoUrl` and `branch` should be pretty intuitive and should point to the Git repository and the name of the branch to publish from.

trans-unit.source: Again, these are defined by input parameters.
trans-unit.target: Again, these are defined by input parameters.

trans-unit.source: Note in the `dependsOn` element that, in addition to the web app resource itself, `sourcecontrols/web` also depends on `config/appsettings` and `config/connectionstrings`.
trans-unit.target: Note in the `dependsOn` element that, in addition to the web app resource itself, `sourcecontrols/web` also depends on `config/appsettings` and `config/connectionstrings`.

trans-unit.source: This is because once `sourcecontrols/web` is configured, the Azure deployment process will automatically attempt to deploy, build, and start the application code.
trans-unit.target: This is because once `sourcecontrols/web` is configured, the Azure deployment process will automatically attempt to deploy, build, and start the application code.

trans-unit.source: Therefore, inserting this dependency helps you make sure that the application has access to the required app settings and connection strings before the application code is run.
trans-unit.target: Therefore, inserting this dependency helps you make sure that the application has access to the required app settings and connection strings before the application code is run.

trans-unit.source: [TODO: need to verify if this is true.]
trans-unit.target: [TODO: need to verify if this is true.]

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] Note also that `IsManualIntegration` is set to `true`.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] Note also that `IsManualIntegration` is set to `true`.

trans-unit.source: This property is necessary in this tutorial because you do not actually own the GitHub repository, and thus cannot actually grant permission to Azure to configure continuous publishing from [ToDoApp](https://github.com/azure-appservice-samples/ToDoApp) (i.e.
trans-unit.target: This property is necessary in this tutorial because you do not actually own the GitHub repository, and thus cannot actually grant permission to Azure to configure continuous publishing from [ToDoApp](https://github.com/azure-appservice-samples/ToDoApp) (i.e.

trans-unit.source: push automatic repository updates to Azure).
trans-unit.target: push automatic repository updates to Azure).

trans-unit.source: You can use the default value `false` for the specified repository only if you have configured the owner’s GitHub credentials in the [Azure preview portal](https://portal.azure.com) before.
trans-unit.target: You can use the default value `false` for the specified repository only if you have configured the owner’s GitHub credentials in the [Azure preview portal](https://portal.azure.com) before.

trans-unit.source: In other words, if you have set up source control to GitHub or BitBucket for any app in the [Azure preview portal](https://portal.azure.com) previously, using your user credentials, then Azure will remember the credentials and use them whenever you deploy any app from GitHub or BitBucket in the future.
trans-unit.target: In other words, if you have set up source control to GitHub or BitBucket for any app in the [Azure preview portal](https://portal.azure.com) previously, using your user credentials, then Azure will remember the credentials and use them whenever you deploy any app from GitHub or BitBucket in the future.

trans-unit.source: However, if you haven’t done this already, deployment of the JSON template will fail when Azure Resource Manager tries to configure the web app’s source control settings because it cannot log into GitHub or BitBucket with the repository owner’s credentials.
trans-unit.target: However, if you haven’t done this already, deployment of the JSON template will fail when Azure Resource Manager tries to configure the web app’s source control settings because it cannot log into GitHub or BitBucket with the repository owner’s credentials.

trans-unit.source: Compare the JSON template with deployed resource group
trans-unit.target: Compare the JSON template with deployed resource group

trans-unit.source: Here, you can go through all the web app’s blades in the [preview portal](https://portal.azure.com), but there’s another tool that’s just as useful, if not more.
trans-unit.target: Here, you can go through all the web app’s blades in the [preview portal](https://portal.azure.com), but there’s another tool that’s just as useful, if not more.

trans-unit.source: Go to the [Azure Resource Explorer](https://resources.azure.com) preview tool, which gives you a JSON representation of all the resource groups in your subscriptions, as they actually exist in the Azure backend.
trans-unit.target: Go to the [Azure Resource Explorer](https://resources.azure.com) preview tool, which gives you a JSON representation of all the resource groups in your subscriptions, as they actually exist in the Azure backend.

trans-unit.source: You can also see how the resource group’s JSON hierarchy in Azure corresponds with the hierarchy in the template file that’s used to create it.
trans-unit.target: You can also see how the resource group’s JSON hierarchy in Azure corresponds with the hierarchy in the template file that’s used to create it.

trans-unit.source: For example, when I go to the [Azure Resource Explorer](https://resources.azure.com) tool and expand the nodes in the explorer, I can see the resource group and the root-level resources that are collected under their respective resource types.
trans-unit.target: For example, when I go to the [Azure Resource Explorer](https://resources.azure.com) tool and expand the nodes in the explorer, I can see the resource group and the root-level resources that are collected under their respective resource types.

trans-unit.source: If you drill down to a web app, you should be able to see web app configuration details similar to the below screenshot:
trans-unit.target: If you drill down to a web app, you should be able to see web app configuration details similar to the below screenshot:

trans-unit.source: Again, the nested resources should have a hierarchy very similar to those in your JSON template file, and you should see the app settings, connection strings, etc., properly reflected in the JSON pane.
trans-unit.target: Again, the nested resources should have a hierarchy very similar to those in your JSON template file, and you should see the app settings, connection strings, etc., properly reflected in the JSON pane.

trans-unit.source: The absence of settings here may indicate an issue with your JSON file and can help you troubleshoot your JSON template file.
trans-unit.target: The absence of settings here may indicate an issue with your JSON file and can help you troubleshoot your JSON template file.

trans-unit.source: Deploy the resource group template yourself
trans-unit.target: Deploy the resource group template yourself

trans-unit.source: The **Deploy to Azure** button is great, but it allows you to deploy the resource group template in azuredeploy.json only if you have already pushed azuredeploy.json to GitHub.
trans-unit.target: The **Deploy to Azure** button is great, but it allows you to deploy the resource group template in azuredeploy.json only if you have already pushed azuredeploy.json to GitHub.

trans-unit.source: The Azure .NET SDK also provides the tools for you to deploy any JSON template file directly from your local machine.
trans-unit.target: The Azure .NET SDK also provides the tools for you to deploy any JSON template file directly from your local machine.

trans-unit.source: To do this, follow the steps below:
trans-unit.target: To do this, follow the steps below:

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, click **File** > **New** > **Project**.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, click **File** > **New** > **Project**.

trans-unit.source: Click **Visual C#** > **Cloud** > **Azure Resource Group**, then click **OK**.
trans-unit.target: Click **Visual C#** > **Cloud** > **Azure Resource Group**, then click **OK**.

trans-unit.source: In **Select Azure Template**, select **Blank Template** and click **OK**.
trans-unit.target: In **Select Azure Template**, select **Blank Template** and click **OK**.

trans-unit.source: Drag azuredeploy.json into the **Template** folder of your new project.
trans-unit.target: Drag azuredeploy.json into the **Template** folder of your new project.

trans-unit.source: From Solution Explorer, open the copied azuredeploy.json.
trans-unit.target: From Solution Explorer, open the copied azuredeploy.json.

trans-unit.source: Just for the sake of the demonstration, let’s add some standard Application Insight resources to our JSON file, by clicking **Add Resource**.
trans-unit.target: Just for the sake of the demonstration, let’s add some standard Application Insight resources to our JSON file, by clicking **Add Resource**.

trans-unit.source: If you’re just interested in deploying the JSON file, skip to the deploy steps.
trans-unit.target: If you’re just interested in deploying the JSON file, skip to the deploy steps.

trans-unit.source: Select **Application Insights for Web Apps**, then make sure an existing App Service plan and web app is selected, and then click **Add**.
trans-unit.target: Select **Application Insights for Web Apps**, then make sure an existing App Service plan and web app is selected, and then click **Add**.

trans-unit.source: You’ll now be able to see several new resources that, depending on the resource and what it does, have dependencies on either the App Service plan or the web app.
trans-unit.target: You’ll now be able to see several new resources that, depending on the resource and what it does, have dependencies on either the App Service plan or the web app.

trans-unit.source: These resources are not enabled by their existing definition and you’re going to change that.
trans-unit.target: These resources are not enabled by their existing definition and you’re going to change that.

trans-unit.source: In the JSON Outline, click **appInsights AutoScale** to highlight its JSON code.
trans-unit.target: In the JSON Outline, click **appInsights AutoScale** to highlight its JSON code.

trans-unit.source: This is the scaling setting for your App Service plan.
trans-unit.target: This is the scaling setting for your App Service plan.

trans-unit.source: In the highlighted JSON code, locate the `location` and `enabled` properties and set them as shown below.
trans-unit.target: In the highlighted JSON code, locate the `location` and `enabled` properties and set them as shown below.

trans-unit.source: In the JSON Outline, click **CPUHigh appInsights** to highlight its JSON code.
trans-unit.target: In the JSON Outline, click **CPUHigh appInsights** to highlight its JSON code.

trans-unit.source: This is an alert.
trans-unit.target: This is an alert.

trans-unit.source: Locate the `location` and `isEnabled` properties and set them as shown below.
trans-unit.target: Locate the `location` and `isEnabled` properties and set them as shown below.

trans-unit.source: Do the same for the other three alerts (purple bulbs).
trans-unit.target: Do the same for the other three alerts (purple bulbs).

trans-unit.source: You’re now ready to deploy.
trans-unit.target: You’re now ready to deploy.

trans-unit.source: Right-click the project and select **Deploy** > **New Deployment**.
trans-unit.target: Right-click the project and select **Deploy** > **New Deployment**.

trans-unit.source: Log into your Azure account if you haven’t already done so.
trans-unit.target: Log into your Azure account if you haven’t already done so.

trans-unit.source: Select an existing resource group in your subscription or create a new one, select **azuredeploy.json**, and then click **Edit Parameters**.
trans-unit.target: Select an existing resource group in your subscription or create a new one, select **azuredeploy.json**, and then click **Edit Parameters**.

trans-unit.source: You’ll now be able to edit all the parameters defined in the template file in a nice table.
trans-unit.target: You’ll now be able to edit all the parameters defined in the template file in a nice table.

trans-unit.source: Parameters that define defaults will already have their default values, and parameters that define a list of allowed values will be shown as dropdowns.
trans-unit.target: Parameters that define defaults will already have their default values, and parameters that define a list of allowed values will be shown as dropdowns.

trans-unit.source: Fill in all the empty parameters, and use the [GitHub repo address for ToDoApp](https://github.com/azure-appservice-samples/ToDoApp.git) in **repoUrl**.
trans-unit.target: Fill in all the empty parameters, and use the [GitHub repo address for ToDoApp](https://github.com/azure-appservice-samples/ToDoApp.git) in **repoUrl**.

trans-unit.source: Then, click **Save**.
trans-unit.target: Then, click **Save**.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] Autoscaling is a feature offered in **Standard** tier or higher, and plan-level alerts are features offered in **Basic** tier or higher, you’ll need to set the **sku** parameter to **Standard** or **Premium** in order to see all your new App Insights resources light up.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] Autoscaling is a feature offered in **Standard** tier or higher, and plan-level alerts are features offered in **Basic** tier or higher, you’ll need to set the **sku** parameter to **Standard** or **Premium** in order to see all your new App Insights resources light up.

trans-unit.source: Click **Deploy**.
trans-unit.target: Click **Deploy**.

trans-unit.source: If you selected **Save passwords**, the password will be saved in the parameter file **in plain text**.
trans-unit.target: If you selected **Save passwords**, the password will be saved in the parameter file **in plain text**.

trans-unit.source: Otherwise, you’ll be asked to input the database password during the deployment process.
trans-unit.target: Otherwise, you’ll be asked to input the database password during the deployment process.

trans-unit.source: That’s it!
trans-unit.target: That’s it!

trans-unit.source: Now you just need to go to the [preview portal](https://portal.azure.com) and the [Azure Resource Explorer](https://resources.azure.com) tool to see the new alerts and autoscale settings added to your JSON deployed application.
trans-unit.target: Now you just need to go to the [preview portal](https://portal.azure.com) and the [Azure Resource Explorer](https://resources.azure.com) tool to see the new alerts and autoscale settings added to your JSON deployed application.

trans-unit.source: Your steps in this section mainly accomplished the following:
trans-unit.target: Your steps in this section mainly accomplished the following:

trans-unit.source: Prepared the template file
trans-unit.target: Prepared the template file

trans-unit.source: Created a parameter file to go with the template file
trans-unit.target: Created a parameter file to go with the template file

trans-unit.source: Deployed the template file with the parameter file
trans-unit.target: Deployed the template file with the parameter file

trans-unit.source: The last step is easily done by a PowerShell cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: The last step is easily done by a PowerShell cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: To see what Visual Studio did when it deployed your application, open Scripts\Deploy-AzureResourceGroup.ps1.
trans-unit.target: To see what Visual Studio did when it deployed your application, open Scripts\Deploy-AzureResourceGroup.ps1.

trans-unit.source: There’s a lot of code there, but I’m just going to highlight all the pertinent code you need to deploy the template file with the parameter file.
trans-unit.target: There’s a lot of code there, but I’m just going to highlight all the pertinent code you need to deploy the template file with the parameter file.

trans-unit.source: The last cmdlet, `New-AzureResourceGroup`, is the one that actually performs the action.
trans-unit.target: The last cmdlet, `New-AzureResourceGroup`, is the one that actually performs the action.

trans-unit.source: All this should demonstrate to you that, with the help of tooling, it is relatively straightforward to deploy your cloud application predictably.
trans-unit.target: All this should demonstrate to you that, with the help of tooling, it is relatively straightforward to deploy your cloud application predictably.

trans-unit.source: Every time you run the cmdlet on the same template with the same parameter file, you’re going to get the same result.
trans-unit.target: Every time you run the cmdlet on the same template with the same parameter file, you’re going to get the same result.

trans-unit.source: Summary
trans-unit.target: Summary

trans-unit.source: In DevOps, repeatability and predictability are keys to any successful deployment of a high-scale application composed of microservices.
trans-unit.target: In DevOps, repeatability and predictability are keys to any successful deployment of a high-scale application composed of microservices.

trans-unit.source: In this tutorial, you have deployed a two-microservice application to Azure as a single resource group using the Azure Resource Manager template.
trans-unit.target: In this tutorial, you have deployed a two-microservice application to Azure as a single resource group using the Azure Resource Manager template.

trans-unit.source: Hopefully, it has given you the knowledge you need in order to start converting your application in Azure into a template and can provision and deploy it predictably.
trans-unit.target: Hopefully, it has given you the knowledge you need in order to start converting your application in Azure into a template and can provision and deploy it predictably.

trans-unit.source: Next Steps
trans-unit.target: Next Steps

trans-unit.source: Find out how to [apply agile methodologies and continuously publish your microservices application with ease](app-service-agile-software-development.md).
trans-unit.target: Find out how to [apply agile methodologies and continuously publish your microservices application with ease](app-service-agile-software-development.md).
